Handcrafted CSS

I'm going to review a few of the best practices I learned from reading Handcrafted CSS: More Bulletproof Web Design by Dan Cederholm. Note: This article is not meant to be walkthrough.

Assignment: Work with floats to create a menu with optimal markup. Keep usability in mind.

Example 1

  • Latte $2.79
  • Cappuccino $2.99
  • Espresso $2.00
  • Half-caf, latte (with a twist of lemon) $10.49

Dan recommended making the entire row clickable including link titles and prices. Why you ask?

Fitts's law: is a model of human movement primarily used in humanâ€“computer interaction and ergonomics that predicts that the time required to rapidly move to a target area is a function of the distance to the target and the size of the target.

So by increasing the clickable area, this will help increase usability and make for a better user experience. Sounds awesome!

I'm already familiar with display: block but I will need to clear my floats when using block-level elements within containers.

overflow: hidden: a method of self-clearing any floats that occur within the container element.

Here is the CSS I added to my list item's a tag:

ul.lst li a { display: block; overflow: hidden; padding: 2%; }
  • Latte $2.79
  • Cappuccino $2.99
  • Espresso $2.00
  • Half-caf, latte (with a twist of lemon) $10.49

Looks ok, but the usability is still bad. I need a divider to visually separate each list item. A hover color to tell the user which item they are selecting is needed as well.

Example 2

Time to make those improvements by adding a bottom border and a hover to my CSS:

ul.lst li a { border-bottom: 1px solid #ddd; display: block; overflow: hidden; padding: 2%; } ul.lst li:hover { background: #fff8dc; }
  • Latte $2.79
  • Cappuccino $2.99
  • Espresso $2.00
  • Half-caf, latte (with a twist of lemon) $10.49

Move your mouse over the different items. Almost perfect, but there are still two issues. Notice the double border at the very bottom? I also want to add a background color to every other row. This should help improve readability.

:nth-of-type(n)

I could create an even and odd class for my background and then apply it to my HTML. Not ideal. By using the :nth-of-type(n) selector we can achieve these results without all the extra markup:

The :nth-of-type(n) selector matches every element that is the nth child, of a particular type, of its parent. N can be a number, a keyword, or a formula.

Just what I need. There are also two keywords I can use to help match child elements:

p:nth-of-type(even)
p:nth-of-type(odd)
Odd and even are keywords that can be used to match child elements whose index is odd or even (the index of the first child is 1).

Now I can set the background color for every other row with no extra markup to my HTML:

ul.lst li:nth-of-type(even) { background: #f8f8f8; }

Next, I need to remove the bottom border on the fourth row to avoid double borders. I used this formula:

(an + b).
A represents a cycle size, n is a counter (starts at 0), and b is an offset value.

Here is what the CSS looks like:

ul.lst li:nth-of-type(4n+0) { border-bottom: 0; }

Example 3: Final results

  • Latte $2.79
  • Cappuccino $2.99
  • Espresso $2.00
  • Half-caf, latte (with a twist of lemon) $10.49

Perfect! I learned how to use optimal code while improving the usability of my design. Check back soon for more examples from my reading of Handcrafted CSS: More Bulletproof Web Design.
